articles.headline: Bush and Hu Vow New Cooperation
articles.snippet: The two leaders made some progress on nuclear proliferation and trade imbalances, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.
articles.abstract: The two leaders made some progress on nuclear proliferation and trade imbalances, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 â€” President Bush and China's president, Hu Jintao, pledged to cooperate more closely on fighting nuclear proliferation and reducing trade imbalances on Thursday, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.

articles.headline: Which Picture of Skilling Will Enron Jurors Believe?
articles.snippet: In eight days on the witness stand Jeffrey K. Skilling accomplished much of what he needed to do in front of the jury hearing his criminal case, avoiding any major gaffes while staunchly maintaining his innocence.      But in the end, the performa...
articles.abstract: In eight days on the witness stand Jeffrey K. Skilling accomplished much of what he needed to do in front of the jury hearing his criminal case, avoiding any major gaffes while staunchly maintaining his innocence.      But in the end, the performance by Enron's former chief executive was far from perfect, and may have revealed to the jury more than he and his lawyer wanted.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, April 20 - In eight days on the witness stand Jeffrey K. Skilling accomplished much of what he needed to do in front of the jury hearing his criminal case, avoiding any major gaffes while staunchly maintaining his innocence.

articles.headline: Are These Hedge Fund Results Real?
articles.snippet: FOR those who favor open markets and open investment management, it may look like the best of times. But it may really be the worst -- and we may not learn just how bad it is until something horrible happens.     Never have American stock and bond...
articles.abstract: FOR those who favor open markets and open investment management, it may look like the best of times. But it may really be the worst -- and we may not learn just how bad it is until something horrible happens.     Never have American stock and bond markets been more transparent and subject to better regulation. New rules protect investors in companies and mutual funds by requiring better disclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE - FOR those who favor open markets and open investment management, it may look like the best of times. But it may really be the worst -- and we may not learn just how bad it is until something horrible happens.

articles.headline: First Bank to Settle I.P.O. Suit
articles.snippet: J. P. Morgan Chase said yesterday that it would pay $425 million to settle its part of a class-action lawsuit that contends dozens of banks cheated investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars from initial public offerings during the 1990's ma...
articles.abstract: J. P. Morgan Chase said yesterday that it would pay $425 million to settle its part of a class-action lawsuit that contends dozens of banks cheated investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars from initial public offerings during the 1990's market boom.     J. P. Morgan is the first to settle of the 55 investment banks named as defendants, and its agreement may prompt other Wall Street firms to follow. Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs are among the largest investment houses involved in the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. P. Morgan Chase said yesterday that it would pay $425 million to settle its part of a class-action lawsuit that contends dozens of banks cheated investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars from initial public offerings during the 1990's market boom.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Pfizer and the Proxy Adviser
articles.snippet: Directors of Pfizer Inc., up for election at the company's annual meeting next Thursday and under fire from shareholders over the pay awarded to executives, got a welcome show of support late last week from one of the nation's three proxy advisory...
articles.abstract: Directors of Pfizer Inc., up for election at the company's annual meeting next Thursday and under fire from shareholders over the pay awarded to executives, got a welcome show of support late last week from one of the nation's three proxy advisory services.      Proxy Governance Inc. of Vienna, Va., urged its investor customers to vote for all 13 of the drug maker's directors. In contrast, the other two advisory firms -- Institutional Shareholder Services of Rockville, Md., and Glass Lewis & Company of San Francisco -- have recommended that Pfizer shareholders withhold their votes from some board members because of the company's pay practices.

articles.headline: Bush and Hu Vow New Cooperation
articles.snippet: President Bush and China's president, Hu Jintao, pledged to cooperate more closely on fighting nuclear proliferation and reducing trade imbalances on Thursday, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.     Th...
articles.abstract: President Bush and China's president, Hu Jintao, pledged to cooperate more closely on fighting nuclear proliferation and reducing trade imbalances on Thursday, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.     The meeting, the first at the White House between the men since Mr. Hu became China's top leader in 2002, was plagued by gaffes that upended months of painstaking diplomacy over protocol and staging.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 - President Bush and China's president, Hu Jintao, pledged to cooperate more closely on fighting nuclear proliferation and reducing trade imbalances on Thursday, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.

articles.headline: Google Posts 60% Gain in Earnings
articles.snippet: Google returned to favor among investors yesterday as its profit for the first quarter increased 60 percent, well above expectations.     Three months ago, the company disappointed investors, even though its profit grew 82 percent, and its stock s...
articles.abstract: Google returned to favor among investors yesterday as its profit for the first quarter increased 60 percent, well above expectations.     Three months ago, the company disappointed investors, even though its profit grew 82 percent, and its stock sagged. This time, Google's ascent was enough to satisfy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google returned to favor among investors yesterday as its profit for the first quarter increased 60 percent, well above expectations.

articles.headline: Democrats Eager to Exploit Anger Over Gas Prices
articles.snippet: Democrats running for Congress are moving quickly to use the most recent surge in oil and gasoline prices to bash Republicans over energy policy, and more broadly, the direction of the country.     With oil prices hitting a high this week and pric...
articles.abstract: Democrats running for Congress are moving quickly to use the most recent surge in oil and gasoline prices to bash Republicans over energy policy, and more broadly, the direction of the country.     With oil prices hitting a high this week and prices at the pump topping $3 a gallon in many places, Amy Klobuchar, a Democratic Senate candidate in Minnesota, is making the issue the centerpiece of her campaign. Ms. Klobuchar says it ''is one of the first things people bring up'' at her campaign stops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 - Democrats running for Congress are moving quickly to use the most recent surge in oil and gasoline prices to bash Republicans over energy policy, and more broadly, the direction of the country.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Dismisses Medical Benefit From Marijuana
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that ''no sound scientific studies'' supported the medical use of marijuana, contradicting a 1999 review by a panel of highly regarded scientists.     The announcement inserts the health agency into y...
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that ''no sound scientific studies'' supported the medical use of marijuana, contradicting a 1999 review by a panel of highly regarded scientists.     The announcement inserts the health agency into yet another fierce political fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 - The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that "no sound scientific studies" supported the medical use of marijuana, contradicting a 1999 review by a panel of highly regarded scientists.

articles.headline: Shiite Drops Bid to Keep Post as Premier
articles.snippet: Under intense domestic and American pressure, Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari dropped his bid to retain his job on Thursday, removing a major obstacle to forming a new government during a time of rising sectarian violence.      Leaders from each...
articles.abstract: Under intense domestic and American pressure, Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari dropped his bid to retain his job on Thursday, removing a major obstacle to forming a new government during a time of rising sectarian violence.      Leaders from each of Iraq's main factions -- Sunni Arab, Shiite and Kurd -- called the decision a breakthrough.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 20 - Under intense domestic and American pressure, Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari dropped his bid to retain his job on Thursday, removing a major obstacle to forming a new government during a time of rising sectarian violence.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: U.S. Crackdown Set Over Hiring of Immigrants
articles.snippet: The apprehension on Wednesday of more than 1,100 illegal immigrants employed by a pallet supply company based in Houston, as well as the arrest of seven of its managers, represented the start of a more aggressive federal crackdown on employers, Ho...
articles.abstract: The apprehension on Wednesday of more than 1,100 illegal immigrants employed by a pallet supply company based in Houston, as well as the arrest of seven of its managers, represented the start of a more aggressive federal crackdown on employers, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said Thursday.      Describing the hiring of millions of illegal workers, in some cases, as a form of organized crime, Mr. Chertoff said the government would try to combat the practice with techniques similar to those used to shut down the mob.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 - The apprehension on Wednesday of more than 1,100 illegal immigrants employed by a pallet supply company based in Houston, as well as the arrest of seven of its managers, represented the start of a more aggressive federal crackdown on employers, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said Thursday.
